Award.AwardTitle: Transcriptome evolution and whole genome duplication
Award.AbstractNarration:
The genomes (total cellular DNA) of flowering plants, including all crop species, have undergone multiple rounds of whole genome duplication (WGD, polyploidy). The availability of duplicated genes, combined with extensive genome remodeling that follows WGD events, gives rise to a wide range of novel traits. It is clear that gene expression mediates many of these responses, and selection on gene dosage may drive gene family and network evolution. Yet surprisingly little is known about how genome duplication affects individual gene expression or the entire transcriptome (the combined expression of all genes in the genome in a given tissue). This project will use a suite of novel approaches to estimate whole transcriptome size and to assay expression changes of genes across the genome in response to WGD. Several synthetic and recently formed natural polyploids and their diploid progenitors will be studied in order to determine both the immediate and longer-term effects of genome duplication on gene expression.
This project is of broad significance and impact because quantifying dosage responses on a genomic scale will clarify our understanding of how selection on gene dosage has shaped plant evolution, leading to important traits in species of agricultural importance, such as soybean, whose close relatives are the targets of this project. In addition, the project funds opportunities for undergraduates to participate in the research, and facilitates scientific collaboration between a major research university (Cornell) and an undergraduate-only institution (Reed College).

POR.DRECONTENT:
All flowering plants, including our most important crops, are polyploid, meaning they have undergone a doubling (or more) of their DNA content. This process of genome multiplication is an important evolutionary phenomenon that causes a wide range of novel traits, including many traits important to agriculture. How such traits arise in response to polyploidy is largely unknown.

The information stored in DNA produces traits through the process of gene expression. The first step in gene expression is transcription - the production of RNA (aka, transcripts) using DNA as a template. Standard gene expression profiling methods quantify the relative concentrations of transcripts but provide no direct information about absolute transcript abundance per cell. Through this project, we developed assays to quantify RNA abundance per cell. This enabled a new and more comprehensive view of the effects of genome doubling on gene expression.

Using these assays, we showed that doubling of DNA content causes an approximately 50% increase in overall transcript abundance, rather than doubling the overall size of the transcriptome. This held true in natural polyploids as well as in laboratory-generated polyploids, in polyploids that were formed via hybridization and those that weren’t, in three different tissue types (leaves, roots, sepals), and in one tissue (roots) under different growth conditions. These data indicate that polyploidy induces partial down-regulation of each genome copy.

Despite this consistent response in terms of global transcriptional output, individual genes show a wide range of expression responses per cell following changes in gene copy number (gene dosage responses). We quantified individual gene dosage responses for most genes in the genomes of three natural polyploids in the genus Glycine and in three synthetic polyploids of the model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana. By mapping these gene dosage responses onto gene networks (functionally interacting genes) we provided the first expression-level support for a leading hypothesis (the Gene Balance Hypothesis) that seeks to explain patterns of genome evolution that have emerged across all plant genomes with polyploid histories. We also continue to use data on absolute gene dosage responses to help dissect the molecular basis for novel traits - such as enhanced photosynthesis and stress tolerance - associated with polyploidy. Cell size increases with polyploidy, and we have shown in Arabidopsis sepals that cell size increase is directly proportional to the increase in transcriptome size, and that genes that function at the cell surface show larger gene dosage responses than do genes functioning in the interior of the cell (Robinson et al. 2018, "Ploidy and size at multiple scales in the Arabidopsis sepal." Accepted pending revision at The Plant Cell).

We have summarized these data on transcriptional responses to polyploidy and discussed how they relate to other recurring patterns associated with genome multiplication in a broader review of cell-level effects of polyploidy (Doyle and Coate, 2018, "Polyploidy, the nucleotype, and novelty: The impact of genome doubling on the biology of the cell." Accepted pending revision at the International Journal of Plant Sciences).
